Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a High Resolution Photon Emission/Electro-Optical Microscope for Non-invasive Evaluation of Electronic Devices and Systems Security

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, acquiring a new high resolution microscope, aims to allow users to analyze the performance of electronic devices and systems. With a user friendly interface and the use of intuition, the instrument is expected to maximize its accessibility for on-site use and for off campus users. The platform will be used for teaching, education, and outreach. This effort is shared by six universities in Florida. The effort enables:
- Remote access capability to reach over 500 students every year both on and off campus;
- Material and expertise on hardware security related topics for educators to incorporate in their classroom curricula;
- Help to bring experts into their classrooms to discuss real-world applications; and
- Exposure of undergraduates to advanced microscopy techniques.
This new high resolution photon emission and electro-optical microscope enables the analysis by visualizing the transistor functionality non-destructively. When analyzing performance in this fashion, maximum impact is gained from multiple features such as:
- New high sensitive detectors that enable high resolution;
- Laser scanning configuration that enable static and dynamic failure analysis;
- Static laser scanning stimulation that contribute to identify the source of shorts and resistive defects; and
- Electro-optical probing and frequency mapping that enable rapid identification of regions of interest.
The unique capabilities of the instrument constitute a critical enabling parameter for research in hardware and system security areas. These include:
- Counterfeit detection by providing more detailed data than general electrical tests in less expensive and non-destructive manner;
- Semi-invasive physical attacks by enabling advanced contactless probing techniques and laser injection to measure circuit activity;
- Trojan detection by performing trust analysis of fabricated integrated circuits for validation of security and trust; and
- Reverse and anti-reverse engineering by complementing conventional reverse engineering and extracting the intellectual property blocks critic information.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A new high resolution (HR) Photon Emission (PEM) and Electro-optical microscope was acquired through this support from NSF. The instrument is featured with a dual illumination unit, an InGaAs camera, a super high resolution (SHR) silicon immerged lens (SIL), a near infrared (NIR) macrolens, and HR NIR lenses from 5X to 100X magnification. This instrument is the only one of its own kind in the state of Florida and in the academia nationwide. It allows users to analyze the performance of electronic devices and systems by visualizing the transistors functionality non-destructively. Electro-optical probing (EOP) and frequency mapping (EOFM) feature can collect HR, high contrast reflected pattern images of working transistors under a wide range of frequency from few KHz to GHz range. The instrument has a long history of usage in different sectors of industry mainly for the purpose of defect detection and localization. However, the recent advancements in the image resolution and performing condition of the instrument have opened new doors to investigate cyber and hardware security problems for electronic devices and systems.  

A large number of researchers at the U of Florida as well as our partner universities and industry collaborators use this instrument. It has enabled a number of breakthroughs that otherwise would have been possible had we not have this instrument in the lab. Several existing projects at UF benefited from the PHEMOS-1000 instrument. This instrument enabled the PIs to establish a closer collaboration with researchers across the nation working in diverse areas of systems security. It supports IC reverse engineering, non-destructive failure analysis, semi-invasive physical attacks, counterfeit detection, hardware Trojan detection, and PCB reverse engineering. The lab modules developed through the course of this project using this instrument is currently being used in physical assurance courses and many training modules offered to professionals in the field of hardware security.
